<<<api>>>: PrintWriter.write
<<<code>>>: 
// Client side
socket = new Socket(host, port);
outStream = socket.getOutputStream();
out = new PrintWriter(outStream, true);
reader = new BufferedReader(new FileReader(file));
...
props.load(reader);
props.store(out, null);
out.write("\n"); // Add this line
out.flush(); // And this line

// Server side
out = new PrintWriter(sock.getOutputStream(), true);
inStream = sock.getInputStream();
in = new BufferedReader( new InputStreamReader(inStream));
...
props.load(in);
<<<explanation>>>: The issue here is that the Properties.store() method does not append a newline at the end of the stream. This means that the BufferedReader on the server side is waiting for a newline to know when to stop reading. By manually appending a newline to the end of the stream on the client side after the call to props.store(out, null), you signal to the server that it has reached the end of the stream and it can stop reading. The flush() method is called to ensure that the newline is actually sent over the socket before the client stops executing.
